Abstract:
$$table_{776FDE40-1C04-43BC-A229-4934E0F3FFFF}$$
The poster will include the information below that highlights St. Baldrick''s contributions to creating the historical Childhood Cancer STAR Act, their work to get it passed and ensure funding for its programs. The poster will hopefully also include progress made in these funded programs, anecdotal stories from patients who have benefitted from them.
Because of the work of the St. Baldrick''s Foundation, the groundbreaking Childhood Cancer STAR Act was passed in 2018. The STAR Act focuses on creating and maintaining biorepositories at the National Cancer Institute, conducting nationwide childhood cancer surveillance programs, and developing best practices for long-term survivorship care. STAR also authorizes $30 million in new federal funding each year for five years.
St. Baldrick''s Foundation developed the STAR Act and crafted and implemented the strategy to get this bill signed into law. While many people and organizations from the pediatric cancer community contributed ideas, resources, and manpower to get the STAR Act to the finish line, St. Baldrick''s compiled and synthesized the policy ideas into one comprehensive legislative package, establishing relationships with key childhood cancer congressional champions, led the effort to build support for STAR on Capitol Hill, and negotiated final legislative language with congressional leadership.
The STAR Act has been funded every year since 2018. Most recently in 2020, Congress provided $80 million for childhood cancer research, $30 million to implement the STAR Act for the third year, and $50 million to implement CCDI for a second year. St. Baldrick''s was critical in making this happen by leading the childhood cancer community''s advocacy strategy and working directly with policymakers to make the case for fully funding both programs.
SOURCE: www.stbaldricks.org

Title: The Childhood Cancer STAR Act: Giving Kids A Lifetime to Thrive and Prosper.

Abstract: Shining Brightly- Howard Brown - 2 time Stage IV Cancer - patient / survivor / advocate. Shining Brightly with cancer will feature modern day cancer survivorship methods. People are living longer with cancer. Digital tools, online networks, telemedicine, enhanced imaging, wearables and healthy living websites, blogs, podcast and video are helping patients and survivor live a more healthy mental and physical life.

SearchResultBody: ADV203. The Face of the Beast
Title: The Face of the Beast

Abstract: Independent Cancer Patients' Voice (ICPV) was set up by patients on the Breast CSG in 2007 because more patients were needed for the workload. ICPV has held study days in Leeds, Velindre, Barts' & The London, the House of Lords, Universities of Birmingham, Sussex, Glasgow, Warwick and Stirling, CRUK, and a Radiotherapy Day in London. The training was formalised into the VOICE (Vision On Information, Confidence & Engagement) Science Course for patient advocates which has been run since 2013 jointly by the Barts’ Cancer Institute and ICPV. So far, the course has trained 56 graduates. ICPV believes that "Clinical research is improved by patients being partners with clinicians and healthcare professionals, rather than passive recipients of healthcare" ICPV was initially almost entirely breast cancer patients, but now has 67 members across most tumour groups, although breast still predominate. ICPV members are now involved in over 95 cancer related National, European and International Committees; the Breast CSG and all Subgroups; have been to NCRI conferences and San Antonio; are on over 100 Trial Management and Steering Groups; have been co-applicants on at least 30 trials; and have also been involved in the initial design of trials. Good examples are treatment reduction trials (PERSEPHONE, PRIMETIME, LORIS & OPTIMA), MENOS4 (Nurse delivered CBT for Hot Flushes) and the SWEET programme (Adherence to endocrine therapy) which are unmet needs highlighted by ICPV members. Other trials include: Add Aspirin, AsCaP, AZURE, POETIC, MAMMO-50, MENOS4, NEPTUNE, PALLET, PEACE, FASTForward, SMALL, ROSCO, IMPORT HIGH & LOW, PRECISION (CRUK Grand Challenge), MyPeBS (Horizon 2020). ICPV is an established partner in cancer research in the UK, has received affirmation from cancer researchers, works with Cancer52, AllTrials, use MY data, BCN, BCN tissue bank, WCRF, the MHRA, HTA, CCB and is a stakeholder with the APPGC, APPGBC, and ABPI

Title: Independent Cancer Patients' Voice, continuing to speak clearly and be heard.

Abstract:

The Inaugural EGFR Resisters Research Summit was held November 15-16, 2019 in Chicago, IL. The goal of the EGFR Resisters Research Summit was to help identify, cultivate, and prepare physician and related clinician and PhD investigators working in targeted lung cancer therapies for successful careers that help to advance the rapidly evolving field of EGFR-mutated lung cancer. The idea to develop a Research Summit focused on EGFR was first proposed at the 2018 Inaugural EGFR Resisters Think Tank. One of the main Call to Action Points from the Think Tank was to expand bench and translational research efforts for EGFRm lung cancer. The involvement of patients in educational planning can increase the relevance, meaning, and impact of CME. Through sharing their experiences, they can provide essential feedback and can guide educators and clinicians in meeting their needs and priorities. Trained patient advocates have been shown to augment translational research, which we have demonstrated our role in early career professional development of lung cancer clinician-scientists. The poster will highlight the impact of the EGFR Research Summit and the involvement of trained patient advocates in advancing the professional development of the next generation of clinician-scientists and the value of the Summit in continuing to advance substantive research in EGFRm NSCLC
SearchResultBody: ADV205. Patient Advocates as Catalysts to Build a Community of EGFR Researchers
Title: Patient Advocates as Catalysts to Build a Community of EGFR Researchers

Abstract: The majority of childhood cancer statistics show kids are 'cured' at 5 years. This is not telling the whole story. The story is many childhood cancers do not have cures, kids are dying and those kids that are headed toward being 'cured' - the side and aftereffects are grand. How do we solve this? Research, research specifically aimed at pediatric cancers. Research needs funding. The steps of achieving government funding are multi-layered, time consuming and an enormous commitment. Learning how to effectively create relationships with lawmakers, navigate the political system and share stories ultimately putting a face to the why the funding is needed, is critical to success. We can work together with others at many levels to achieve our ultimate end goal, saving children's lives.
SearchResultBody: ADV206. When a Cure Isn't Really A Cure
Title: When a Cure Isn't Really A Cure

Title: Navigation in the Brain Tumor World through BrainCloud

Abstract: Beginning in 1981 when my spouse was diagnosed with a transitional cell carcinoma in her kidney, I began my journey of service as a a cancer educator and advocate, co-leading patient support/education groups with the local chapter of the ACS. This Journey of Service has continued till today, November 2021, a period of 40 years, with plans to continue as long as I am physically and mentally able to effectively serve as a cancer survivor advocate, educator and activist. Along the way there have various obstacles and barriers which had to be overcome in order to serve as an advocate/educator, these barriers will be identified and the strategies used to overcome them will be described in detail.
SearchResultBody: ADV208. A Personal Journey of. Service of a Cancer Survivor Advocate
Title: A Personal Journey of. Service of a Cancer Survivor Advocate

Abstract: The Project encourages young women to seek medical attention promptly by educating them on the signs, symptoms, and risks of breast cancer. Most women under 40 find their breast abnormalities themselves and have no family history of disease, which gives them a false sense of security that they are “too young” and “not at risk” for breast cancer. To do this, The Project has a three-pillar approach: (1) we use data and stories that we collect from the survivor community to educate our physicians on the difficulties that the majority of young women face getting diagnosed with accuracy and urgency; (2) we connect to young women and all young people with breasts through creative, fun, captivating events and social media on breast health; (3) we provide an opportunity for storytelling and open dialogue amongst young survivors and those affected by the disease to promote personal healing and a greater sense of community within the Young Breast Cancer community. We plan to establish a communication loop with physicians to improve the timeliness from detection to diagnosis of breast cancer, in effect helping women to start treatment sooner and/or identify those who are high-risk sooner. Through these efforts, The Project serves to decrease the rate of delayed and difficult diagnosis among young women of average risk and women with hereditary risk.
SearchResultBody: ADV209. AYA Breast cancer age disparities and lack of breast health education.
Title: AYA Breast cancer age disparities and lack of breast health education.

Abstract: Check for a Lump's mission: Provide free breast health education, mammograms, testing, and direct assistance to breast cancer patients with wigs, support, and resources in Arizona. Education Program: Empowering women in Arizona and beyond with invaluable breast health facts and preventive information. Distribution through annual magazine (70,000), STEP UP to Prevention Wellness Workshops, social media, website and other media outlets. Mammogram Program: Providing free mammograms and all diagnostic testing necessary for diagnosis of breast cancer to qualifying women in Arizona. Clients apply online and, once approved, Check for a Lump is directly billed by the imagining company partners. We also host mammogram events through mobile mammography units. Wig Program: Impacting women in Arizona undergoing chemotherapy treatment for breast cancer with a free wig; providing them the comfort and normalcy they deserve. Clients apply online and, once approved, may select a wig of choice up to $250 at one of our approved wig shops, and Check for a Lump pays the bill. Super Survivors support group: Supporting breast cancer patients, survivors, and their caregivers by hosting free Super Survivors Unite gatherings. The support program started in 2020 and the launch was heavily effected by Covid-19. Moving forward, we hope to expand the Super Survivors Unite to provide more opportunity, both virtual and in person, for our community to connect over their shared experiences.Q20
Title: Check for a Lump

Abstract: I will be presenting this poster as an independent advocate exploring pre-menopause, early-stage diagnosis HR+ patients, and the impact on fertility and conception. I was diagnosed at 33 years old before having children with minimal understanding of my family planning options. The intended constituency is young women diagnosed under the age of 40.
